lessonTitle: The Boundary as Ontological Act: From Distinction to Civilization

questions.question: What are the three irreducible poles of reality created by the act of abstraction?
questions.correct_answer: The Observed (that which is on this side of the boundary), The Observer (the one for whom the distinction is drawn), and The Non-observed or Nothing (the fundamental background from which the boundary is drawn).

questions.question: According to the lesson, what is the starting point before the act of abstraction occurs?
questions.correct_answer: A pre-reflective state of undifferentiated Being - not chaos, but wholeness where there is neither subject nor object.

questions.question: What are the two possible modes of relating to another Observer's boundary?
questions.correct_answer: Ignoring his boundary (which leads to violence and appropriation) or recognizing his boundary (which leads to cooperation and exchange).

questions.question: Name the six quantum levels of civilization mentioned in the lesson, in order.
questions.correct_answer: Family, Kinship/Clan, Tribe, Nation, Religion, and Civil Society.

questions.question: What do the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse represent in the context of this lesson?
questions.correct_answer: They represent systemic forces unleashed when civilization destroys its own internal boundaries: White Horse (erases local boundaries), Red Horse (war within society), Black Horse (violation of just distribution), and Pale Horse (destruction of ecological equilibrium).
